headline: Photos: Second Democratic Presidential Debate
summary: Democratic presidential hopefuls sparred on stage in the second debate of the 2020 election. Thursday’s session featured the second half of the 20 candidates who made the cut. Here are some photos from the event.

headline: Boeing 737 MAX Likely Grounded Until Late This Year
summary: Boeing troubled 737 MAX fleet is expected to stay grounded until late this year as a result of the latest flight-control problem flagged by U.S. air-safety regulators.

headline: A Second Act for RealReal’s CEO
summary: Julie Wainwright, who was chief executive of online pet supply retailer Pets.com, which closed months after joining the stock market in 2000, is back with another initial public offering.

headline: Lawsuit Alleges Government Mistreatment of Migrant Children
summary: Immigrant rights attorneys have filed suit against the Trump administration, claiming that the federal government is holding children in unhealthy and unsafe conditions along the Southwest border in violation of a settlement.

headline: Yada Yada: ‘Seinfeld Experience’ to Come to Gramercy
summary: Some might say that New York City already is like a ‘Seinfeld’ episode come to life. But now, the city also will play host to an immersive exhibit that bills itself as a chance for fans to truly tap into the 1990s sitcom’s world.

headline: Nike Posts Strong Sales, Plays Down Trade Risks
summary: Nike posted higher sales in the latest quarter, boosted by strong demand in both the U.S. and China, and executives said the trade dispute between the two countries hasn’t hurt the sneaker giant’s business.

headline: Biotech Companies Soar in Stock Market Debuts
summary: Investors betting on the growth prospects of life-sciences startups sent the shares of three biotechnology companies soaring in their stock market debuts.

headline: U.S. Charges Former and Current Venezuelan Electricity Officials
summary: The U.S. government stepped up pressure on Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro on Thursday, blacklisting two individuals with ties to his regime and charging them with corruption.

summary: The Great War’s horrors, spiritual emptiness and a pack of lies made another world war inevitable.

headline: Grim Lizzie
summary: Warren’s odd brand of populism seeks to expand a corrupt system’s power.

headline: Religious Suppression North of the Border
summary: American politicians shouldn’t be afraid to stand up for the faithful in Canada.

headline: ‘Rockonomics’ Review: Making Money in the Music Biz
summary: With recording income in flux these days, performers now rely primarily on concert revenue. Ticket prices have risen accordingly.

summary: This luxurious property was owned by Lamar Hunt, the late Kansas City Chiefs founder who is widely credited with coining the term ‘Superbowl’.

headline: Wayfair’s Wayward Walkout
summary: What’s the point of denying furniture for detained migrants?

summary: The Justices are wise to step away from policing partisan redistricting.

summary: Netflix’s series looks at the final days of the Romanovs and the hubris that contributed to their downfall.

headline: No Time to Go Cold on Conagra

headline: Apple Design Chief Jony Ive to Depart
summary: Apple said its chief design officer, Jony Ive, will leave this year to form an independent design company, with Apple being one of its primary clients.

headline: Ford to Slash Jobs as Part of European Shake-Up
summary: Ford detailed plans to close factories in Europe and cut 12,000 jobs, or more than 20% of the company’s workforce there, an effort to focus on technologies that are reshaping the auto industry.

headline: Iran Threatens to Pull Out of Nuclear Treaty, Like North Korea

headline: Twitter to Flag Officials’ Tweets That Break Rules
summary: The social-media platform said it would begin flagging tweets by government officials and political figures world-wide who violate Twitter’s rules, a response to longstanding criticism that could court new controversy.

headline: FDA Says Medtronic Insulin Pumps Pose Cybersecurity Risk
summary: The Food and Drug Administration warned that certain insulin pumps made by Medtronic have cybersecurity vulnerabilities and could be manipulated by hackers, causing danger to diabetes patients.

headline: North Carolina Regulators Seize Control of Life Insurers Owned by Greg Lindberg
summary: North Carolina’s insurance department seized control of a group of troubled life insurers owned by Greg Lindberg, who was arrested in April on federal criminal charges of conspiring to bribe the state’s insurance commissioner.

headline: ‘The Loudest Voice’ Review: A Fox in the Hen House
summary: A series about Roger Ailes paints the ideological executive as a power-hungry malefactor surrounded by virtuous underlings.

headline: Federal Reserve Clears Big Banks to Boost Payouts to Investors
summary: The Fed cleared the biggest banks to increase shareholder payouts, another sign the industry has grown fit enough to handle a severe economic shock.

summary: A mine partially owned by Glencore collapsed in the Congo, killing at least 19 people who were mining illegally, the London-listed company said.

summary: Banks are boosting dividends and buyouts following their stress tests, but shares could still struggle.

headline: White Supremacist Propaganda Spreads on Campuses
summary: White supremacist groups are ramping up their advertising on U.S. college campuses, with more cases of extremist propaganda in spring 2019 than any prior semester, according to a new report from the Anti-Defamation League.

headline: Catholics Debate the Future of Priestly Celibacy
summary: A shortage of priests has led to calls to ease rules that have governed the church for centuries.

headline: Manafort Pleads Not Guilty to 16 State Charges
summary: Paul Manafort pleaded not guilty to 16 criminal charges in a case in which state prosecutors have accused the former Trump campaign chairman of falsifying business records to illegally obtain millions of dollars in residential mortgages.

headline: Democratic Primary Debate Draws 15.3 Million Viewers

headline: Bank of Mexico Maintains Interest Rates in Split Vote
summary: The Bank of Mexico kept interest rates unchanged Thursday in a split decision, citing risks for inflation from both domestic and external sources and a worsening outlook for economic growth.

headline: New York City Jail Plan Is Dividing Communities
summary: Some residents are pushing back as New York City leaders lay the groundwork to close the Rikers jail complex and build four new facilities within the next seven years.

headline: Social-Media Users Weigh In on First Democratic Debate
summary: Elizabeth Warren drew the most Twitter traffic while Tulsi Gabbard was the most googled and Bill de Blasio attracted responses from various platforms.

headline: SpaceX Is Seeking More Capital From Investors
summary: Elon Musk’s SpaceX is in the middle of another fundraising round, as it tries to ramp up various rocket and spacecraft projects. The company is looking to raise $314 million, which would value the company at about $31 billion.

headline: At NATO Meeting, Pentagon’s New Leader Issues Call to Counter Iran
summary: Acting Secretary of Defense Mark Esper urged North Atlantic Treaty Organization allies on Thursday to join the U.S. in countering what he called Iran’s malign activities in the Persian Gulf, in a first outing on the world stage for the former industry executive-turned-Pentagon chief.

headline: Senate Passes Measure Taking Aim at Chinese Banks Doing Business With North Korea
summary: The Senate took aim at Chinese banks that do business with North Korea, voting to ban them from the U.S. financial system as part of the massive annual Pentagon authorization legislation.

headline: Real-Estate Developer Howard Hughes Hires Adviser to Explore Possible Sale
summary: Howard Hughes Corp. is exploring strategic options including a possible sale of the company, a move that comes as the real-estate developer has received a chilly reception from Wall Street.

headline: ‘Yesterday’: A World With No Beatles

headline: ‘Maiden’ Review: Women Making Waves

headline: ‘Midsommar’ Review: Horror in the Summer Sun

headline: ‘The Quiet One’ Review: A Humble Rock ’n’ Roller
summary: Bill Wyman, a longtime but virtually invisible member of the Rolling Stones, gets a pleasingly modest documentary treatment in Oliver Murray’s new film.

headline: Sapphire Reserve Strains JPMorgan’s Ties With United Airlines
summary: JPMorgan’s Sapphire Reserve has been a hit with frequent travelers and big spenders since its launch nearly three years ago. That is a problem for United, which wants those same customers to sign up for and spend on the airline’s credit cards.

headline: Florida Red Tide Blamed for 174 Dolphin Deaths

summary: The board at Canadian tour operator Transat A.T. Inc. agreed to a takeover by Air Canada, at a price below what another bidder has offered.

headline: How Jam-Packed Will My Train Be? Google Says It Has the Answer

It is a question that Google Maps will hope to help answer with a new rollout: a transit feature that predicts crowdedness levels across mass transit.

headline: Financier Bill Browder Plays the Long Game to Expose Russian Money-Laundering

summary: Under recent loosening of social rules, they have more opportunities to meet romantic interests, but dating is still complicated in a still-highly traditional society. ‘I’m shocked by how daring they are.’

summary: The property includes a 6,456-square-foot house, a guesthouse, an outdoor pool, a tennis court and a treehouse Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis built for her grandchildren.

headline: Nissan CEO Faces Deadline to Fix U.S. Problems
summary: A strong shareholder vote of discontent this week against Nissan Motor’s chief executive has put him on a tight timeline to turn around the Japanese auto maker’s troubled U.S. operations.

summary: Magellan Health, furniture maker Herman Miller, KB Home, and Rite Aid are among Thursday’s stocks to watch.

summary: Airlines reinforced their call for air-safety regulators to cooperate on returning the Boeing 737 MAX plane to service and agreeing on common pilot training requirements after two fatal crashes.

summary: The pace of U.S. economic growth remained at a strong 3.1% annual rate in the first three months of the year, but a downward revision to consumer spending suggests the momentum could be difficult to maintain.

headline: U.S. Jobless Claims Rose Last Week
summary: The number of Americans filing applications for new unemployment benefits rose last week, amid deepening concerns that trade disputes and slowing global growth are starting to affect the domestic economy.

headline: Why Helicopters Are Sinking Offshore
summary: The energy business has turned up its fair share of casualties in industries associated with the supply chain. This cycle it is the helicopter.

headline: Harry Potter Augmented-Reality Game Is Off to a Slow Start

headline: Russell Rebalancing Promises Trading Frenzy
summary: A surge in trading is expected Friday as stocks are added to and dropped from FTSE Russell’s U.S. benchmarks. During last year’s rebalancing, about $100 billion of individual stocks were traded in the final seconds of the day.

headline: Trump and Xi Have Reason to Step Back From the Brink
summary: Both the U.S. and China are heading into the G-20 loudly proclaiming they don’t need a deal. The reality is that both economies have already suffered substantial damage—and the next round of tariffs would make things far worse. A further escalation isn’t inevitable though.

summary: German authorities said they had arrested a suspect wanted in connection with the 2015 Islamic State terrorist attack in Paris.

summary: For all the discussion of a global role for the yuan, China’s banks still need access to the dollar system, while U.S. banks don’t need the yuan.

headline: U.S. Women’s Soccer Players Sought Lawsuit Talks
summary: As the World Cup approached, U.S. women’s soccer players tried to meet with U.S. Soccer president Cordeiro to end their long pay fight with the federation.

summary: Chinese technology giant Huawei defended itself against allegations that it violates other companies’ intellectual-property rights, saying it has never been forced by a court to pay fines for stealing secrets.

summary: The DOJ’s inspector general is examining whether senior officials in the FBI’s Los Angeles field office acted inappropriately by attending a 2018 Dodgers playoff game, while a corruption investigation into Major League Baseball was unfolding.

summary: Australian officials are urgently seeking information about an Australian man in North Korea following reports he had been detained by authorities in Pyongyang.

summary: Executive Philip Geier made over 200 acquisitions and cultivated enduring ties with leaders of Coca-Cola, Unilever and Nestlé

summary: Cannabis can’t cross state lines today, but should federal laws change, high-cost growers and areas with less favorable climates for cannabis growing will be undercut.

summary: Advanced Micro Devices revived its fortunes when it decided to help Chinese partners develop computer-chip technology. The deal sparked a prolonged battle with Washington over national security.

headline: Jackie O’s Compound on Martha’s Vineyard Hits Market for $65 Million
summary: Caroline Kennedy is listing the 340-acre property, which her mother bought for over $1 million in the late 1970s.

headline: When It Comes to Tariffs, Many U.S. Companies Are on China’s Side
summary: As President Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping gear up for the G-20 summit, U.S. businesses are warning that new 25% duties on $300 billion a year of Chinese goods will wreak widespread direct and collateral damage.

headline: Democrats Unite Against Trump, Divide on Health Care in First Debate
summary: Ten Democratic presidential candidates squared off in their first joint appearance, laying bare an intraparty dispute over the future of the nation’s health-care system while offering a united front in denouncing President Trump’s policies.
